info.game_comments:
Kristin Sausville game 2.
Single-player Final Jeopardy!

jeopardy_round: TEAM OF THE WORLD SERIES MVP

(1, 1).clue: A stroke while fighting to get the Treaty of Versailles ratified disabled him for the last 17 months of his term

(2, 1).clue: 1999:We open with a closer, Mariano Rivera

(3, 1).clue: After marrying an American, he moved to the U.S., where he wrote the 2 "Jungle Books"

(4, 1).clue: Giving a play-by-play of an event while on Twitter is called doing this

(5, 1).clue: What's now this "club" that many join happily was first distilled in Ontario in 1858

(6, 1).clue: On season 2 of "American Idol", Clay Aiken wasn't the winner but this

(1, 2).clue: At his Texas ranch, this President would terrify passengers by driving 90 mph sipping scotch from a foam cup

(2, 2).clue: 1988:Orel Hershiser, though one swing could've done it for Kirk Gibson, too

(3, 2).clue: He wrote "The War in the Air" as well as "The War of the Worlds"

(4, 2).clue: This 4-letter word is "warm" when the computer's power is already on, "cold" when it's off

(5, 2).clue: During prohibition this family of rum makers invited Americans to Cuba for weekend-long parties

(6, 2).clue: It comes in cherry as well as the original lemon-lime

(1, 3).clue: Boxing in the White House in the early 20th century left him blind in one eye, a secret he kept for years

(2, 3).clue: 2001:Randy Johnson & Curt Schilling, southwestern brothers in arms

(3, 3).clue: John Fowles' best-known work is this 1969 novel that was made into a movie starring Meryl Streep

(4, 3).clue: In Windows hitting Ctrl-C & Ctrl-V performs these 2 artsy & crafty actions

(5, 3).clue: The letters "V.O.P." on the label of a bottle of cognac stand for this

(6, 3).clue: Common exercise done in a prone position, or a type of bra

(1, 4).clue: Orphaned by age 9, this 31st President was raised by Quaker relatives in Oregon

(3, 4).clue: Here's this beloved author giving a reading circa 1860

(4, 4).clue: This process that maximizes disk space is so named because it joins up pieces of files that were stored separately

(5, 4).clue: The name of this honey-whiskey liqueur is from a Scottish Gaelic phrase that means "the drink that satisfies"

(6, 4).clue: A thorough medical exam including lab tests & X-rays; your doctor might order one on you

(1, 5).clue: In the last year of his presidency in 1844, he secretly married a woman 30 years younger

(3, 5).clue: Sharing the nickname "The Queen of Crime" are Agatha Christie & this author of the Adam Dalgliesh mysteries

(4, 5).clue: Releasing someone's personal info on the Internet is this word that can have 1 or 2 "X"s in the middle

(5, 5).clue: This Italian liqueur is made from tonda gentile hazelnuts grown in the Piedmont region

(6, 5).clue: It's another name for an Apache wigwam

(1, 1).clue: Charles Stratton was almost 5 when Phineas T. Barnum gave him this name; he would remain 25'' tall & 15 lbs. until his teens

(2, 1).clue: Although named for an Italian city, these window coverings with slats may have originated in Persia

(4, 1).clue: In 2004 President Roh Moo Hyun tried to move South Korea's capital from this city to Gongju

(5, 1).clue: His lyrics after the death of his brother George include "The Man Who Got Away", music by Harold Arlen

(6, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew delivers the clue next to the monitor.) The brightest star in the constellation of this archer is Kaus Australis, from the Arabic for "bow" & Latin for "southern", respectively

(1, 2).clue: Edna Ferber's 1958 novel "Ice Palace" was so compelling that it helped this attain statehood the next year

(2, 2).clue: Using urethane for this molding at the juncture of wall & ceiling will allow you to use adhesive instead of nails

(4, 2).clue: One of this Japanese city's most popular tourist destinations is the atomic bomb Genbaku Dome

(5, 2).clue: Johnny Mercer came out here in 1935 & co-wrote the 1937 song "Hooray for" it

(6, 2).clue: This constellation is where you'll find the sun as spring begins in the Northern Hemisphere

(1, 3).clue: I cannot tell a lie, but Barnum sure could; in 1835 Phineas marketed Joice Heth as a 161-year-old ex-nurse to this man

(2, 3).clue: This home furnishings chain founded in 1962 "imports" more than 70% of its merchandise from China & India

(4, 3).clue: This Mongolian city is often described as the world's coldest capital

(5, 3).clue: A statue of this "Yankee Doodle Dandy" inscribed "GIve My Regards to Broadway" stands opposite Times Square

(6, 3).clue: His water jug is pouring a stream of about 30 faint stars toward the brighter star Fomalhaut

(2, 4).clue: The most popular pattern for this geometric inlaid wood flooring is herringbone

(4, 4).clue: This country's 2nd-largest city, Mandalay, is known for a pagoda containing 729 stone Buddhist tablets

(5, 4).clue: Oscar Hammerstein II & this other great partner of Richard Rodgers were classmates at Columbia

(6, 4).clue: Spica, her brightest star, is held in her left hand

(1, 5).clue: This 1924 Ferber novel about a widow managing a farm & son was just huge, winning a Pulitzer

(2, 5).clue: In 2013 this interior decorator & HGTV personality published her first book, "The Well-Traveled Home"

(3, 5).clue: Speaking this way involves similes & metaphors

(4, 5).clue: This Vietnamese city near the Gulf of Tonkin serves as the deepwater port for Hanoi

(5, 5).clue: This nickname of "Over the Rainbow" lyricist E.Y. Harburg was a shortening of Young People's Socialist League

(6, 5).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew wraps up the category for us.) Latin for "little king", Regulus is the brightest star of this constellation, and is said to be its "heart"

(0, 0).clue: On August 15, 1994, 59 years & 1 day after FDR signed the original act, Bill Clinton made this an independent agency
